text:
RAE JOHNSON: I was probably
a kinesthetic learner
when I was a kid.

And I always felt as though the
experience of my moving body

was this remarkable source
of pleasure and wonder

and discovery, but I
didn't feel as though there

were very many
places in my world

where that was something
that I could cultivate.

And it wasn't until
many years later,

when I trained to be a
psychotherapist, that I

came across a field of
psychotherapy called body

psychotherapy, and sometimes
called somatic psychology,

and I realized
that I didn't need

to keep my love of the
body and my fascination

with the human psyche and
who we are as a species

and what makes us tick,
that I didn't actually

need to keep those two
things separate anymore.

The body and our senses,
our physical senses

are not these untrustworthy,
infantile, unreliable,

problematic things that
are only good for carrying
our head around.

But in fact, our bodies
are who we are, and we

lose a big part of
who we are and we

lose a lot of the
richness of life

when we agree to allow
that part of ourselves
to be marginalized.

There are really three areas
of focus in my own research.

The first is there is,
across many cultures

and throughout history,
this remarkable subjugation

and denial of the lived,
felt experience of a body

and that part of the task of
addressing social inequities

is actually a task
for everyone, which

is to find ways to come
back into our own skins

and be present and to occupy
ourselves from the inside out.

But beyond that, there's
also this huge territory

of body image and
the degree to which

members of socially-subordinated
and subjugated groups

are made to believe that
there is something inherently,

irrevocably wrong and/or
bad about their bodies
that they can do nothing about.

The third territory that
my research investigates

has to do with our
non-verbal communication.

About 75% of all of our
interpersonal communication,

when we do it in person,
happens on a body level,
and it's not what we say.

It's what our bodies are
saying as we're speaking
the words that we're speaking.

And when we're faced with a
contradiction between what

someone is speaking and
what their body is saying,
it's the body we believe.

And so one of the
implications for that,

in terms of social
justice work, is

that if we don't
interrogate the messages

that our bodies are
relaying to each other,

whether the people that
we're communicating with

are members of social
groups different from ours

in salient ways or
whether there's a power

imbalance, that those
messages can really undermine
or reinforce power inequities.

And there's just tons
of really good research

in nonverbal communication
that suggests

that if we want to undo macro
level systems of oppression,

one of the important and
unrecognized dimensions

of systemic oppression is the
everyday, micro-sociological,

body-to-body ways in which we
reproduce those dynamics all
the time.

I think that there are
two things going on,

and it's going to be fascinating
to discover how we mutate
as a species on this one.

Because there does seem
to be some early evidence

that younger people seem
to be willing to tolerate

a much greater variety of bodily
expression than ever before.

On the other hand,
we're also entering

a world in which most
of those young people

spend a good chunk of their
lives in a disembodied state

because they are
interacting with technology

and interacting with one another
in a very disembodied way.

So in terms of what's the
cutting edge in our field,

that's a territory,
the relationship

between the psyche and the
soma and, perhaps, the cyborg.
